oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Have Invasive Mysids (Mysis diluviana) Altered the Capacity of Osoyoos Lake, British Columbia to Produce Sockeye Salmon (Oncorhynchus nerka)?
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Hyatt, Kim D.
McQueen, Donald J.
Ogden, Athena D.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: sockeye salmon
aquatic invasion
Mysis diluviana
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: <jats:sec><jats:title>Background:</jats:title><jats:p>During 2005-13, at Osoyoos Lake, British Columbia, we investigated trophic relationships among fry of<jats:italic>Oncorhynchus nerka</jats:italic>Walbaum (Sockeye and kokanee), a suite of limnetic planktivores including<jats:italic>Mysis diluviana</jats:italic>, and their zooplankton prey.</jats:p></jats:sec><jats:sec><jats:title>Objectives:</jats:title><jats:p>Our goal was to quantify the impacts that a recently introduced population of<jats:italic>Mysis</jats:italic>would have on density, growth and survival of resident age-0 Sockeye Salmon.</jats:p></jats:sec><jats:sec><jats:title>Methods:</jats:title><jats:p>Evidence of<jats:italic>Mysis</jats:italic>impact was based on (<jats:bold>a</jats:bold>) simple correlation analysis between various biophysical performance measures and (<jats:bold>b</jats:bold>) production and bioenergetics models used to identify the strength of bottom-up (<jats:italic>i.e</jats:italic>. production-driven) and top-down (<jats:italic>i.e.</jats:italic>consumption-driven) processes.</jats:p></jats:sec><jats:sec><jats:title>Results:</jats:title><jats:p>This nine-year study indicated that the Osoyoos Lake food web was strongly influenced by external events These included: large annual variations in river discharge, an earthen dam failure and effluent input from an Okanagan River tributary, and highly variable recruitment of<jats:italic>O. nerka</jats:italic>fry given out-of-basin factors (harvest, marine survival) controlling adult salmon returns. Surprisingly, large annual variations in<jats:italic>O. nerka</jats:italic>recruitment (0.63 - 7.0 million fry), did not induce significant “top-down” associations in growth, survival or subsequent production among the macro-planktivores (pelagic fish and<jats:italic>Mysis</jats:italic>) and their zooplankton prey. A single significant correlation (p ≤ 0.05) between<jats:italic>O. nerka</jats:italic>fry abundance and their von Bertalanffy<jats:italic>W</jats:italic><jats:sub>∞</jats:sub>parameter emerged from a set of 14 potential top-down associations tested. By contrast, we identified several strongly positive “bottom-up” effects in which survival of<jats:italic>O. nerka</jats:italic>fry was significantly associated (p ≤ 0.01) with annual variations in total zooplankton biomass,<jats:italic>Daphnia</jats:italic>biomass and<jats:italic>Epischura</jats:italic>biomass. Our results indicate that<jats:italic>Mysis</jats:italic>played a dual role in the Osoyoos Lake pelagic food web. As predators, they accounted for an average (June-October) of 64% of the total prey biomass consumed by fish and<jats:italic>Mysis</jats:italic>. As prey,<jats:italic>Mysis</jats:italic>contributed an average of 35% of the prey biomass consumed by fish. Consumption by fish and<jats:italic>Mysis</jats:italic>together accounted for daily losses of only 4.5% of non-mysid zooplankton biomass and 34% of daily zooplankton production.</jats:p></jats:sec><jats:sec><jats:title>Conclusion:</jats:title><jats:p>We conclude that in all years, combined prey consumption by<jats:italic>Mysis</jats:italic>and fish was never high enough, acting alone, to reduce the availability of their potential zooplankton forage base. However, we also estimate that in the absence of<jats:italic>Mysis</jats:italic>,<jats:italic>O. nerka</jats:italic>fry could experience a 43% increase in their daily food intake and that fish and<jats:italic>Mysis</jats:italic>might control their principal prey taxa when exogenous factors (<jats:italic>e.g.</jats:italic>annual discharge) induced major reductions in zooplankton biomass. Finally, although<jats:italic>Mysis</jats:italic>has clearly altered the energy flow pathways from plankton to fish in the Osoyoos Lake food-web, mysids have not precluded rebuilding<jats:italic>O. nerka</jats:italic>abundance to levels at or exceeding historic maxima.</jats:p></jats:sec>
